content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see multiple fragments of fibrofatty tissue, consistent with a lymph node dissection. There are at least five well-defined, basophilic (purple) structures that are clearly lymph nodes of varying sizes. My initial task would be to systematically evaluate each of these nodes for evidence of metastasis.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area because it contains one of the lymph nodes that need to be assessed. This is the second lymph node from the top on the left side of the image. I need to examine its architecture and cellular composition at higher magnification to determine if it is benign (reactive) or if it contains metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary goal for this slide is to determine if any of the lymph nodes contain metastatic tumor cells (i.e., are positive). I need to examine every lymph node meticulously. The area indicated by the green box contains one of the larger, well-defined lymph nodes located in the upper left quadrant. It is a logical starting point for a systematic review of all the lymph nodes on the slide. I am zooming in to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high power. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my protocol for a lymph node dissection is to systematically examine each lymph node present on the slide. The green box highlights one of these lymph nodes, located in the lower central portion of the image. I would zoom into this area to assess its architecture and cytology at high magnification, specifically to look for any signs of metastatic tumor, such as the presence of atypical glandular structures or clusters of non-lymphoid cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist examining a colorectal cancer case, the primary objective is to meticulously screen every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed on one of the lymph nodes, specifically the one at the bottom right. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic examination of all lymph nodes on the slide. Pathologists examine the entire node, including the subcapsular sinus, the cortex, and the medulla, as these are common sites for initial metastatic deposits. This specific zoom is focused on the periphery of the node, a critical area to assess for tumor cell infiltration. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my procedure is to systematically examine every lymph node on the slide. The green box is located on one of the larger lymph nodes (the third one from the top, on the right side). I would zoom into this area as part of the routine high-power examination of this node to assess its architecture, including the capsule, subcapsular sinus, and parenchyma, and to meticulously search for any atypical cells or tumor deposits that would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to examine every lymph node on the slide for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed over one of the candidate lymph nodes (the one on the middle right). I would systematically zoom into each lymph node to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high magnification. This particular node appears to have a somewhat irregular outline and internal structure, warranting a closer look to differentiate between reactive changes (like prominent germinal centers) and tumor infiltration. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically scan the entire slide for any lymphoid tissue or suspicious cellular aggregates. The area indicated by the green box highlights a small, isolated, darkly stained cluster of cells that is separate from the larger, more obvious lymph nodes. It is crucial to examine such small foci at high power to determine their nature. The differential diagnosis for this small 'blue dot' includes a small reactive lymph node, a tertiary lymphoid aggregate, or, most critically, a tumor deposit (satellite nodule), which would impact the N-stage (classifying it as N1c if it's a tumor deposit without residual lymph node tissue). Therefore, zooming in is essential for accurate staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a lymph node with a somewhat distorted but largely preserved architecture. It is composed of dense lymphoid tissue with follicular structures. The sinuses appear open and show some sinus histiocytosis, which is a reactive finding. The lymphocytes appear small and mature. I do not see any clear evidence of metastatic adenocarcinoma, such as atypical glands, nests of large pleomorphic cells, or desmoplastic stromal reaction. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the detailed histology of the lymph node. It is composed of a dense, diffuse population of lymphocytes. I can discern lymphoid follicles, which are the normal structural units of a lymph node. The cells are predominantly small lymphocytes with round, dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. I do not see any definite evidence of metastatic tumor, such as atypical glandular formations, nests of large epithelial cells with pleomorphic nuclei, or signet-ring cells, which would be expected from a colorectal adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression of this specific area is that it represents a benign, reactive lymph node, likely negative for metastasis. I would continue to scan the rest of this node and then proceed to examine the other lymph nodes on the slide.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a section of a lymph node. The parenchyma is densely packed with a population of small lymphocytes with dark, round nuclei and scant cytoplasm. I do not see any definitive evidence of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glands, large pleomorphic cells, or desmoplastic stromal reaction. The overall impression of this specific lymph node is that it is benign and reactive, showing no signs of metastasis. It is a negative lymph node.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a portion of a lymph node adjacent to mature adipose tissue. The lymph node tissue consists of a dense population of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are morphologically consistent with lymphocytes. These cells are arranged in a nodular pattern. The lymph node appears to be encapsulated. Within this specific field of view, there are no obvious atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or signet ring cells to suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. The impression of this specific area is that it shows benign lymphoid tissue. However, a complete examination of the entire lymph node at high power is necessary to definitively rule out the presence of micrometastasis.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the periphery of a lymph node. On the right, there is a dense and monotonous population of small, dark, round cells consistent with mature lymphocytes. On the left is mature adipose tissue. A thin fibrous capsule separates the lymphoid tissue from the surrounding fat. I do not see any nests of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or significant cytologic atypia within the lymphoid parenchyma or the subcapsular sinus. My impression of this specific area is that it represents a benign or reactive lymph node, with no evidence of metastasis in this field of view. The rest of the lymph node and all other nodes on the slide must be examined to make a final diagnosis.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense and monotonous population of small, round cells with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. These cells form sheets and vague nodules. I do not see any atypical glandular structures, clusters of large cells with pleomorphic nuclei, or significant necrosis that would suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. The overall impression of this specific field is that of a benign lymph node, likely showing some reactive changes. There is no evidence of metastasis in this particular area.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image reveals a dense, nodular aggregate of cells infiltrating the adipose tissue. The cells are uniformly small, with round, dark (hyperchromatic) nuclei and scant cytoplasm. These morphological features are consistent with mature lymphocytes. I do not see the characteristic features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as glandular formation, cellular pleomorphism, large vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli, or eosinophilic cytoplasm. My impression is that this is a benign lymphoid aggregate, also known as tertiary lymphoid structure, or possibly a very small, completely effaced lymph node. Importantly, there is no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in this specific field of view.
